column1: No major changes for 2021 Summary: Total Known Tower Sites – 144 Total Towers Still Standing – 55 Total Towers Gone or Removed – 89 Tower survey results are based on reports gathered from hundreds of sources throughout the year. Some information may not be current. The information on each tower was current and to the best of our knowledge as of the date in the Last Update field in the table.
column2: Of the 55 Standing Towers: Standing Steel Only
column3: No Cab – 22 Standing Steel Converted to Observ. – 6 Standing Steel and Cab – 26 Standing Wooden Enclosed – 1 Average Condition of the 26 Standing Towers with Cabs: Good Condition – 11 Fair Condition – 4 Poor Condition –5 Bad Condition –6

column2: This number coresponds to where this tower is on the map.
Indicates if the tower is standing or gone. If standing
column3: indicates at least steelwork is standing. See condition for further information.

column2: Average condition of tower. Possible choices are: Good
column5: or Bad - indicates overall condition Structure Only - No Cab - indicates the steelwork still stands
column6: but the cab is no longer in place Structure Only - Observation - indicates the cab was removed and has been converted to an observation deck

column2: The survey year that the condition was observed
Indicates the level of accessibility. Possible choices are: AOP - Accessible to the public. Indicates a generally maintained tower as part of state land
column4: or a tower that is open by a private land owner. AOR - Accessible
column5: but access at your own risk. Indicates that the tower may be accessible
column6: but is not a maintained tower and is not likely safe to climb. Towers in this category should not be climbed without permission of the owner. They may also be closed by their owner or marked or posted to not enter. Visitors to these towers should respect tower owner and land owner postings. AWO - Accessible only when opened. Indicates a maintained tower
column7: but may only be opened when either an opening is scheduled or a volunteer watchman is present. NRA - Not readily accessible. Towers in this category are not typically accessible due to owner modification or extreme deterioration of stairs
column9: or cab. Visitors to these towers should not attempt climbing under any circumstances.

column2: The elevation of the summit where the tower resides.
The tower height in feet. A ? mark means unknown. 1-

column1: Maine Fire Tower Links and Updates

Regular updates and information on Maine Fire Towers can be found on the Forest Fire Lookout Association Maine Chapter Facebook Page. The main timeline page is public and can be read without a Facebook account. A Facebook account is still needed if you would like to post and participate in conversation. Updates to Maine Fire Tower inventories can still be found on this page We encourage corrections
column3: and commetns. These and any inquiries can be sent by email to maine@firelookout.org or contact us on Facebook at the above link. Dave Hilton Web Site The old Dave Hilton Maine Tower web site can still be found at this link - From York to the Allagash-Forest Fire Lookouts of Maine
